caption: A pleasant little green space next to the Sorbonne and some museums. A good place to take a break after wondering around the area as the garden itself has some interesting sculptures and history, you ever get tour guides coming through here so it’s definitely worth you time to sit here with a sandwich and relax. Enjoy Paris l!

Square Paul-Painlevé is located just outside the important Musée de Cluny. Originally created in 1900, the square was redesigned in 2000 to resemble a museum garden centred around the medieval theme. Opening hours are around 9am to 6 or 7pm depending no the season.  This square is rather tiny. What makes it interesting are the numerous monuments placed upon its grounds. These include the She-wolf of Rome, the fountain monument to Octave Géard, a contemporary bust sculpture of Pierre Puvis de Chavannes as well as the Michel de Montaigne statue.  You can conveniently browse Square Paul-Painlevé in 10-15 minutes before or after your visit to the museum. Then continue onward with other intended sightseeing.
Lots of nice flowers and greenery with church however lots and lots of homeless people sleeping there so beware when going there as some areas smell and are occupied
Small park in central Paris with seating opposite the sorbonne. Great for a breather from the hustle and bustle of the city
Gorgeous park, feels like a different era, between the Sorbonne and the medieval castle of Cluny !
Pretty nice place to sit and read.
A place where you can relax from long walks in Paris
Beautiful garden.
mm
Nice
Good for kids
It's a small, well-maintained park with sculptures, pretty plants, and book boxes filled with books in English.

A pretty square facing the Collège de France on one side and the other of the Cluny museum, well laid out, decorated with several statues including the she-wolf Capitoline and outside Montaigne, works of art which evoke education public, education, culture and tolerance. A paper mulberry, an elm and a weeping apple tree adorn the site, to be seen again when they flower. A beautiful tribute to Samuel Paty.
It's a small park with a large, colorful central massif which gives you the impression of being isolated when you sit on a bench. Don't miss the statue of Romus and Romulus.

This small square, formerly Square Paul Painlevé, is ideally located between the Sorbonne and the Hotel de Cluny where the Museum of the Middle Ages and the Cluny thermal baths are located. Well shaded, it is decorated with fragrant plants and statues. Unfortunately rue des Écoles is a little noisy, but it is a good place to rest for a while during a walk on bd St Germain, St Michel for example. I noticed a slight lack of benches.  To have

Tiny and sometimes poorly frequented (marginals, tramps, etc.), useful: the dog does his business there naturally (picked up of course...), the center is bushy and exuberant, it's fashionable, beautiful flowers from time to time …
Samuel Paty Square is a green space located in the 5th arrondissement of Paris, near the Sorbonne and the Musée de Cluny. Worth seeing
Small square between La Sorbonne and the Cluny museum. Quiet for a little break in the neighborhood
This square was inaugurated in 2021 at the initiative of a municipal elected official from Sainte Savine to honor the memory of Samuel Paty, killed by a Muslim fanatic and terrorist.
A pleasant place to relax.
A very cute little square, with its benches, its flowers and statues. It is also in front of the medieval house of Paris, so it is wonderful to rest a little there.
Commemorative anniversary of his assassination by a radicalized Islamist... Moving,
This square is not maintained. It's a shame.
Beautifully flowered and landscaped. Opposite the Sorbonne. Beautiful and necessary tribute to history professor Samuel Paty.
Quiet not too many people. Perfect for peaceful thoughts.
Disappointed by the non-event. So many crowds watching a desperately closed door

Small square in a wonderful location between the Cluny Museum and the Sorbonne. Majestic Siberian elm. I did not give a 5th star because benches have been removed for several months without explanation. So very few places to sit...

Ah, back in time, a peaceful place, well planted, few people for the neighborhood, but it is still August.  A little hello to Montaigne in deep thought and a little hidden by the plants. Perfect for quiet reading
Very pretty park, a little open to the wind and cold, but pleasant benches, pretty robins, and interesting statues
Small garden with the pleasant surprise of finding a statue depicting the Capitoline she-wolf: pleasant surprise.

Contemplate the green spaces, look closely, they are alive! Populated by long-tailed hairy beasts (rats for the faint-hearted), I suppose that's why there's a ban on dogs. In short, there are much more beautiful parks than this one.
Charming little square, a stone's throw from Boulevard Saint Michel, between the Sorbonne and the Cluny Museum. Beautiful trees, calm, what you need to take a break.

Beautiful to walk in, also very nice and all the parks we visited were super clean. We were in the midst of protests over garbage and a day of important confrontations there but we did not see what was seen on TV in the cultural sites everything was super organized and with its boxes of normal garbage in the only place we saw an alley with garbage was in the Latin neighborhood, it was the only one but you couldn't see it, you had to go through the alley to see the rest everything was super good

It's a small garden just opposite Sorbonne University very pleasant calm and to rest for a few moments. This garden is located in the center of Paris 75005

One of the jewels of Paris, great sculptures, and paintings from various periods, its frescoes, the Grandiosas of Louis .The immense paintings of Napoleon's coronation as Emperor. It would be endless to continue. A pleasant experience, for a lifetime. Superior
